definition: to brave the wind and the billows (idiom); to have high ambitions
four horse military chariot (archaic)/four (archaic)/generic term for history books
to ride/to mount/to make use of/to avail oneself of/to take advantage of/to multiply (math.)/Buddhist sect or creed
broken/damaged/worn out/lousy/rotten/to break, split or cleave/to get rid of/to destroy/to break with/to defeat/to capture (a city etc)/to expose the truth of

sentences.english: Timmerman showed him how it was built to sail against the wind and turn into the waves.
sentences.chinese: 提莫曼給他說明了如何造船才能乘風破浪而行。

sentences.english: The ship of China-US relations, moored for so long, again set sail, braving the wind and waves.
sentences.chinese: 停航許久的中美關係大船又乘風破浪啓航了。

sentences.english: The ship buffeted her way through the waves.
sentences.chinese: 這艘船乘風破浪地前進。

sentences.english: As the "Bonadventure" no longer existed, six months at least would be required for the construction of a new vessel.
sentences.chinese: 乘風破浪號已經沒有了，造一隻新船至少要六個月。

sentences.english: South China City Center Building, like a sail, a symbol of the winds and waves of the helmsman.
sentences.chinese: 華南城中心大廈，像個船帆，象徵着乘風破浪的舵手。

sentences.english: He finds it exciting to ride a motorboat through the sea waves.
sentences.chinese: 駕着摩托艇在海上乘風破浪的感覺，讓他覺得很刺激。

sentences.english: Singaporeans have ridden the wave of increasing wealth throughout Asia.
sentences.chinese: 新加坡的經濟在亞洲財富快速增長的浪潮中乘風破浪。

sentences.english: And we live beneath the waves in our yellow submarine.
sentences.chinese: 在黃色潛水艇裏我們乘風破浪。

sentences.english: You can't stop the waves, but you can learn how to surf.
sentences.chinese: 繅人無法阻止潮起潮落，卻可以學會乘風破浪。

sentences.english: Our ship is cleaving her way through the strait.
sentences.chinese: 我們的船正乘風破浪通過海峽。

definition: to stand tall and see far (idiom); taking the long and broad view/acute foresight
to scull (with a single oar, usually mounted on the stern of the boat)
Formosa (from Ilha Formosa, "Beautiful Isle", the name given to Taiwan Island by passing Portuguese mariners in 1544)

(last line of the poem 望岳 by Tang poet Du Fu 杜甫[Du4 Fu3]) with one look I shall see all the smaller mountains down below (from the summit of Mt Tai 泰山[Tai4 Shan1])/(fig.) awe-inspiring view from a very high place
sea breeze/sea wind (i.e. from the sea)
to ride the wind/to use a fair wind/to take an opportunity
